summary: This document is an email chain from August 2019 between the U.S. Attorney's Office for the Southern District of New York (USANYS) and the Office of the Inspector General (OIG) regarding requests for Jeffrey Epstein's prison commissary records and those of other inmates. The emails specifically seek records of payments made to Epstein and others from certain individuals after his arrest on July 6, 2019.

persons.name: Mariel Colon Miro
persons.role: Person of interest making commissary payments
persons.context: A person from whom commissary payments were made to inmates after July 6, 2019, as requested by the US Attorney's Office.

persons.name: Darren Indyke
persons.role: Person of interest making commissary payments
persons.context: One of the individuals from whom the US Attorney's Office requested records of commissary payments made to inmates after July 6, 2019.

persons.role: Person of interest making commissary payments
persons.context: One of the individuals from whom the US Attorney's Office requested records of commissary payments made to inmates after July 6, 2019.

persons.context: One of the individuals from whom the US Attorney's Office requested records of commissary payments made to inmates after July 6, 2019.

persons.role: Person of interest making commissary payments
persons.context: One of the individuals from whom the US Attorney's Office requested records of commissary payments made to inmates after July 6, 2019.

persons.name: Efrain Reyes
persons.context: An inmate for whom the US Attorney's Office specifically requested commissary records from after July 6, 2019.

persons.name: Jeffrey Epstein
persons.context: The primary subject of the investigation; the email chain discusses his prison commissary account and records of money he received from three different people while incarcerated.

connections.description: Indyke is one of the individuals from whom the prosecution sought records of payments made to Epstein's prison commissary account after his arrest.
Schantz is one of the individuals from whom the prosecution sought records of payments made to Epstein's prison commissary account after his arrest.

Kahn is one of the individuals from whom the prosecution sought records of payments made to Epstein's prison commissary account after his arrest.
The prosecution sought records of any commissary payments made by Mariel Colon Miro to inmate Efrain Reyes after July 6, 2019.

events.title: Epstein's Arrest/Detention Date
events.description: The date from which the prosecution is seeking commissary payment records, marking the period after Jeffrey Epstein was taken into federal custody.

events.title: OIG Provides Epstein's Commissary Records
events.description: The Office of the Inspector General sends an email with attached commissary records and an official BOP photo of Jeffrey Epstein to the US Attorney's Office and other agencies.

events.title: Prosecution Requests Expanded Commissary Records
events.description: The US Attorney's Office emails the OIG to request additional commissary records for payments from specific individuals to inmates, including Epstein, after July 6, 2019.

keyFacts: The U.S. Attorney's Office was actively investigating financial transactions to Jeffrey Epstein and other inmates in the federal prison system shortly after Epstein's arrest in July 2019.
Jeffrey Epstein's prison commissary account showed only three transactions, where he received money from three different people.

The prosecution sought records of commissary payments made by several specific individuals—Darren Indyke, Jeffrey Schantz, Gulnora Tali, Richard Kahn, and Mariel Colon Miro—to inmates after July 6, 2019.
The document indicates coordination between the U.S. Attorney's Office, the FBI, and the DOJ's Office of the Inspector General in gathering evidence related to Epstein's incarceration.
